what: birdsize for the Breeding Bird Survey
title: bbs-data
text: birdsize written interface naturally data North American Breeding Bird Survey (Pardieck et al. 2019). Beginning data BBS route, birdsize can directly simulate body size basal metabolic rate measurements calculate year- species-wide summary statistics.

previous_headings: birdsize for the Breeding Bird Survey
title: bbs-data
text: Data releases Breeding Bird Survey available ScienceBase, e.g. . Data Retriever also provides interface downloading recent releases. Instructions installing Data Retriever R available . birdsize includes demo dataset column names Breeding Bird Survey data available ScienceBase Retriever, synthetic data. explanation column names, see Help page demo_route_raw metadata available ScienceBase.

previous_headings: birdsize for the Breeding Bird Survey
title: bbs-data
text: Following Harris et al. (2018), recommended filter raw BBS data remove taxa poorly sampled via BBS methods (e.g. nightbirds, waterbirds) remove unidenitifed taxa. filter_bbs_survey function performs cleaning:

previous_headings: birdsize for the Breeding Bird Survey
title: bbs-data
text: community_generate function generate individual-level size BMR estimates individuals recorded community data frame type available ScienceBase, Retriever, included demo data: first 15 columns (record_id AOU) retained input data. species BBS, sim_species_id identical AOU used species identification. scientific_name gives scientific name associated AOU. individual_mass individual_bmr individual-level mass BMR estimates, one individual recorded input data. mean_size, sd_size, abundance, sd_method give parameters used generate individual-level estimates.

previous_headings: birdsize for the Breeding Bird Survey
title: bbs-data
text: Harris DJ, Taylor SD, White EP. 2018. Forecasting biodiversity breeding birds using best practices. PeerJ 6:e4278 https://doi.org/10.7717/peerj.4278 Pardieck, K.L., Ziolkowski Jr., D.J., Lutmerding, M., Aponte, V., Hudson, M-.R., 2019, North American Breeding Bird Survey Dataset 1966 - 2018 (ver. 2018.0): U.S. Geological Survey, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center, https://doi.org/10.5066/P9HE8XYJ.

title: birdsize
text: birdsize simulates mass measurements (g) birds. Working assumption individuals species body masses normally distributed around species-wide mean standard deviation, birdsize simulates individual-level body mass measurements drawing species-specific normal distributions. parameters built-450 bird species, user may supply mean optionally standard deviation values additional species. core functions birdsize apply 3 levels organization: species, population, community: species_* functions take information real hypothetical species look calculate parameters necessary simulate body size distributions species. population_* functions use species-level parameters abundances (population sizes) simulate individual body size basal metabolic rate measurements make populations species. community_* functions generate individual body mass estimates multiple populations one go (e.g. populations different species, populations species different points time different sampling locations).

title: birdsize
text: order generate body mass estimates species, birdsize needs abundance value (many individuals generate estimates ) least one : one 450 species known birdsize: scientific name ("Genus species") AOU numeric code. See LINK list species data included birdsize. species: mean body mass (g) species. standard deviation value provided, used. Otherwise, estimated based mean body mass via scaling relationship described scaling vignette. species_define function uses information provided look , calculate, mean standard deviation body mass use generate individuals desired species. function usually operates hood, may interest advanced users interested complex simulations involving changes species-wide parameters.

title: birdsize
text: birds known birdsize can use species’ code (AOU) simulate population directly. hummingbird Selasphorus calliope:
code: a_hundred_hummingbirds <- pop_generate(abundance = 100, AOU = 4360)  head(a_hundred_hummingbirds) #>    AOU sim_species_id individual_mass individual_bmr mean_size   sd_size #> 1 4360           4360        2.556873       20.50623      2.65 0.1818394 #> 2 4360           4360        3.101904       23.53533      2.65 0.1818394 #> 3 4360           4360        2.833263       22.06327      2.65 0.1818394 #> 4 4360           4360        2.703245       21.33652      2.65 0.1818394 #> 5 4360           4360        2.612003       20.82052      2.65 0.1818394 #> 6 4360           4360        2.987874       22.91515      2.65 0.1818394 #>   abundance  sd_method      scientific_name #> 1       100 AOU lookup Selasphorus calliope #> 2       100 AOU lookup Selasphorus calliope #> 3       100 AOU lookup Selasphorus calliope #> 4       100 AOU lookup Selasphorus calliope #> 5       100 AOU lookup Selasphorus calliope #> 6       100 AOU lookup Selasphorus calliope  ggplot(a_hundred_hummingbirds, aes(individual_mass)) +   geom_histogram(bins = 25) +   xlab("Mass (g)") +   ylab("Count") +   ggtitle("A population of hummingbirds")

what: Using a known mean and standard deviation
title: birdsize
text: Alternatively, can simulate body masses population supplying body size parameters . may useful like work species included birdsize, test sensitivities different parameter ranges, generate values simulation/null models (, applications!). Note , mean mass species code provided, species code used mean mass provided ignored!
code: a_hundred_hypotheticals <- pop_generate(abundance = 100, mean_size = 25, sd_size = 3)  head(a_hundred_hypotheticals) #>   AOU sim_species_id individual_mass individual_bmr mean_size sd_size abundance #> 1  NA              1        19.86281       88.44888        25       3       100 #> 2  NA              1        22.60234       96.98414        25       3       100 #> 3  NA              1        20.76744       91.30263        25       3       100 #> 4  NA              1        26.59827      108.92055        25       3       100 #> 5  NA              1        23.80690      100.64180        25       3       100 #> 6  NA              1        24.14694      101.66465        25       3       100 #>              sd_method scientific_name #> 1 Mean and SD provided            <NA> #> 2 Mean and SD provided            <NA> #> 3 Mean and SD provided            <NA> #> 4 Mean and SD provided            <NA> #> 5 Mean and SD provided            <NA> #> 6 Mean and SD provided            <NA>  ggplot(a_hundred_hypotheticals, aes(individual_mass)) +   geom_histogram(bins = 25) +   xlab("Mass (g)") +   ylab("Count") +   ggtitle("A population of hypothetical birds", subtitle = "Mean mass = 25 g\nStandard deviation = 3")

what: Using a known mean, but no standard deviation
title: birdsize
text: mean mass known provided, pop_generate estimate standard deviation based scaling mean standard deviation body mass:
code: another_hundred_hypotheticals <- pop_generate(abundance = 100, mean_size = 25)  head(another_hundred_hypotheticals) #>   AOU sim_species_id individual_mass individual_bmr mean_size  sd_size #> 1  NA              1        26.24416      107.88463        25 1.746196 #> 2  NA              1        21.44791       93.42580        25 1.746196 #> 3  NA              1        20.79538       91.39020        25 1.746196 #> 4  NA              1        23.75958      100.49914        25 1.746196 #> 5  NA              1        22.17191       95.66364        25 1.746196 #> 6  NA              1        22.58620       96.93474        25 1.746196 #>   abundance              sd_method scientific_name #> 1       100 SD estimated from mean            <NA> #> 2       100 SD estimated from mean            <NA> #> 3       100 SD estimated from mean            <NA> #> 4       100 SD estimated from mean            <NA> #> 5       100 SD estimated from mean            <NA> #> 6       100 SD estimated from mean            <NA>  ggplot(another_hundred_hypotheticals, aes(individual_mass)) +   geom_histogram(bins = 25) +   xlab("Mass (g)") +   ylab("Count") +   ggtitle("A population of hypothetical birds", subtitle = "Mean mass = 25 g\nStandard deviation = 1.74")

title: birdsize
text: community_generate takes dataframe species-level information (AOU, scientific name, mean /standard deviation body mass) population sizes, returns dataframe individual-level mass BMR measurements entries input data frame.

title: birdsize
text: , use synthetic dataset records AOU abundance 5 species, make community: community_generate can take table generate simulated individual measurements additional tweaks. uses AOU abundance columns toy_aou_community look species’ mean standard deviation body masses based AOU draw individual size measurements normal distribution parameters. resulting table one row per individual, unique individual_size individual_bmr estimate individual. can plot individual size distribution community, colored species ID:
code: data("toy_aou_community")  head(toy_aou_community) #> # A tibble: 5 × 2 #>     AOU abundance #>   <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1  4730        95 #> 2  3000        40 #> 3  3280        63 #> 4  3860        69 #> 5  4460        53 toy_aou_sims <- community_generate(community_data_table = toy_aou_community, abundance_column_name = "abundance")  head(toy_aou_sims) #>    AOU sim_species_id individual_mass individual_bmr mean_size  sd_size #> 1 4730           4730        38.82847       142.6440    37.475 3.300613 #> 2 4730           4730        40.41270       146.7697    37.475 3.300613 #> 3 4730           4730        42.74367       152.7569    37.475 3.300613 #> 4 4730           4730        34.45230       130.9863    37.475 3.300613 #> 5 4730           4730        36.21842       135.7394    37.475 3.300613 #> 6 4730           4730        42.32158       151.6799    37.475 3.300613 #>   abundance  sd_method scientific_name #> 1        95 AOU lookup Alauda arvensis #> 2        95 AOU lookup Alauda arvensis #> 3        95 AOU lookup Alauda arvensis #> 4        95 AOU lookup Alauda arvensis #> 5        95 AOU lookup Alauda arvensis #> 6        95 AOU lookup Alauda arvensis toy_aou_sims$`Scientific name` = toy_aou_sims$scientific_name  ggplot(toy_aou_sims, aes(individual_mass, fill = `Scientific name`)) +   geom_histogram(position = "stack") +   scale_fill_viridis_d() +   scale_x_log10() +   ggtitle("Community simulated via AOU") +   xlab("Body mass (g)") +   ylab("Number of individuals") +   theme(legend.position = "bottom", legend.direction = "vertical") #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: birdsize
text: AOU known provided, community_generate attempt look species’ size parameters based scientific name. community_generate still runs, note sd_method listed Scientific name lookup rather AOU lookup ().
code: data("toy_species_name_community")  head(toy_species_name_community) #> # A tibble: 5 × 2 #>   scientific_name        abundance #>   <chr>                      <dbl> #> 1 Alauda arvensis               95 #> 2 Bonasa umbellus               40 #> 3 Elanus leucurus               63 #> 4 Coccyzus minor                69 #> 5 Tyrannus melancholicus        53 toy_species_name_sims <- community_generate(toy_species_name_community, abundance_column_name = "abundance")  head(toy_species_name_sims) #>    AOU sim_species_id individual_mass individual_bmr mean_size  sd_size #> 1 4730           4730        39.97640       145.6382    37.475 3.300613 #> 2 4730           4730        38.37580       141.4563    37.475 3.300613 #> 3 4730           4730        37.62253       139.4709    37.475 3.300613 #> 4 4730           4730        39.98764       145.6674    37.475 3.300613 #> 5 4730           4730        38.66003       142.2025    37.475 3.300613 #> 6 4730           4730        37.95838       140.3575    37.475 3.300613 #>   abundance              sd_method scientific_name #> 1        95 Scientific name lookup Alauda arvensis #> 2        95 Scientific name lookup Alauda arvensis #> 3        95 Scientific name lookup Alauda arvensis #> 4        95 Scientific name lookup Alauda arvensis #> 5        95 Scientific name lookup Alauda arvensis #> 6        95 Scientific name lookup Alauda arvensis toy_species_name_sims$`Scientific name` = toy_species_name_sims$scientific_name  ggplot(toy_species_name_sims, aes(individual_mass, fill = scientific_name)) +   geom_histogram(position = "stack") +   scale_fill_viridis_d() +   scale_x_log10() +   ggtitle("Community simulated via scientific name") +   xlab("Body mass (g)") +   ylab("Number of individuals") +   theme(legend.position = "bottom", legend.direction = "vertical") #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: birdsize
text: species name AOU known, included dataset (see known_species full set included species), estimates can still generated providing mean , available, standard deviation body mass directly. standard deviation provided, used; , estimated based scaling relationship mean standard deviation body mass birds (see scaling vignette). functionality may especially useful users interested using parameter values, rather relying ones provided birdsize. example, birdsize take account temporal geographic variation body size, may significant. user manually provide values explore scenarios. Note 1) mean body size data must provided column named mean_size 2) sim_species_id column acts species identifier absence taxonomic information:
code: data(toy_size_community)  head(toy_size_community) #> # A tibble: 5 × 3 #>   abundance mean_size sim_species_id #>       <dbl>     <dbl>          <int> #> 1        95      37.5              1 #> 2        40     532                2 #> 3        63     346                3 #> 4        69      63.9              4 #> 5        53      37.4              5 toy_size_sims <- community_generate(toy_size_community, abundance_column_name = "abundance")  head(toy_size_sims) #>   AOU sim_species_id individual_mass individual_bmr mean_size  sd_size #> 1  NA              1        39.74559       145.0382    37.475 2.625949 #> 2  NA              1        38.47302       141.7117    37.475 2.625949 #> 3  NA              1        35.73167       134.4362    37.475 2.625949 #> 4  NA              1        41.46384       149.4816    37.475 2.625949 #> 5  NA              1        38.36155       141.4188    37.475 2.625949 #> 6  NA              1        37.59558       139.3997    37.475 2.625949 #>   abundance              sd_method scientific_name #> 1        95 SD estimated from mean            <NA> #> 2        95 SD estimated from mean            <NA> #> 3        95 SD estimated from mean            <NA> #> 4        95 SD estimated from mean            <NA> #> 5        95 SD estimated from mean            <NA> #> 6        95 SD estimated from mean            <NA> toy_size_sims$`Sim species ID` <- as.character(toy_size_sims$sim_species_id)  ggplot(toy_size_sims, aes(individual_mass, fill = `Sim species ID`)) +   geom_histogram(position = "stack") +   scale_fill_viridis_d() +   scale_x_log10() +   ggtitle("Community simulated via mean body size") +   xlab("Body mass (g)") +   ylab("Number of individuals") +   theme(legend.position = "bottom") #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. Pick better value with `binwidth`.

title: birdsize
text: body size measurements generated birdsize estimates generally best-suited large-scale, aggregate analyses. bigger-picture analyses, use general aggregation summary functions generate community-wide summaries. example, using dplyr:

previous_headings: Community (multiple populations) simulations > Community-wide summary statistics
title: birdsize
code: toy_species_name_sims_summary <-   toy_species_name_sims |>   group_by(scientific_name) |>   summarize(     total_mass = sum(individual_mass),     total_n_individuals = n()   )  toy_species_name_sims_summary #> # A tibble: 5 × 3 #>   scientific_name        total_mass total_n_individuals #>   <chr>                       <dbl>               <int> #> 1 Alauda arvensis             3566.                  95 #> 2 Bonasa umbellus            21273.                  40 #> 3 Coccyzus minor              4409.                  69 #> 4 Elanus leucurus            21765.                  63 #> 5 Tyrannus melancholicus      1980.                  53

previous_headings: Community (multiple populations) simulations > Community-wide summary statistics
title: birdsize
code: toy_species_name_sims_totals <-   toy_species_name_sims |>   summarize(     total_mass = sum(individual_mass),     total_n_individuals = n(),     total_species_richness = length(unique(scientific_name))   )  toy_species_name_sims_totals #>   total_mass total_n_individuals total_species_richness #> 1   52992.77                 320                      5

title: species
text: birdsize includes species-level parameters 443 species birds common North American Breeding Bird Survey. view list species included, examine known_species data table, included: Species included known_species can retrieved via either AOU scientific name. example, hummingbird Selasphorous calliope AOU 4360.
code: head(known_species) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>     AOU genus      species     #>   <int> <chr>      <chr>       #> 1  2881 Perdix     perdix      #> 2  2882 Alectoris  chukar      #> 3  2890 Colinus    virginianus #> 4  2920 Oreortyx   pictus      #> 5  2930 Callipepla squamata    #> 6  2940 Callipepla californica

title: species
species
text: Note sd_method field tells us method used look parameters. field propagates throughout pop_generate community_generate functions keep track underlying methodology.
code: hummingbird_name_parameters <- species_define(scientific_name = "Selasphorus calliope")  hummingbird_name_parameters #> $AOU #> [1] 4360 #>  #> $scientific_name #> [1] "Selasphorus calliope" #>  #> $mean_size #> [1] 2.65 #>  #> $sd_size #> [1] 0.1818394 #>  #> $sd_method #> [1] "Scientific name lookup" #>  #> $sim_species_id #> [1] 4360

title: species
text: Attempting use species_define AOU species known birdsize return error:
code: try(species_define(AOU = 100)) #> Error in species_lookup(AOU = AOU) : `AOU` is invalid. try(species_define(scientific_name = "Swiftus Taylor")) #> Error in species_lookup(scientific_name = scientific_name) :  #>   Scientific name is invalid.

title: species
text: users may want use methodology species included known_species, use different species-level parameters built-birdsize (example, explore intraspecific variation body size time space). , supply species_define mean, mean standard deviation, values species. help keep track species-parameter matches, use sim_species_id field assign species identifier novel species.

title: species
text: Suppose want work hypothetical species mean body size 40g standard deviation 2.5. species doesn’t scientific name AOU included birdsize, label using arbitrary sim_species_id 1. can particularly useful working multiple new species. example, 3 new species, can store information separate table iterate sim_species_id generate parameters species. happens hood community_generate. standard deviation provided, species_define estimate (see scaling vignette):
code: hypothetical_species_parameters <- species_define(mean_size = 40, sd_size = 2.5, sim_species_id = 1)  hypothetical_species_parameters #> $AOU #> [1] NA #>  #> $scientific_name #> [1] NA #>  #> $mean_size #> [1] 40 #>  #> $sd_size #> [1] 2.5 #>  #> $sd_method #> [1] "Mean and SD provided" #>  #> $sim_species_id #> [1] 1 multiple_species_info <- data.frame(   mean_size = c(10, 40, 50),   sd_size = c(1, 2.5, 3),   sim_species_id = 1:3 )   pmap_df(multiple_species_info, species_define) #> # A tibble: 3 × 6 #>     AOU scientific_name mean_size sd_size sd_method            sim_species_id #>   <int> <chr>               <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>                         <int> #> 1    NA NA                     10     1   Mean and SD provided              1 #> 2    NA NA                     40     2.5 Mean and SD provided              2 #> 3    NA NA                     50     3   Mean and SD provided              3 multiple_species_info_no_sd <- data.frame(   mean_size = c(10, 40, 50),   sim_species_id = 1:3 )   pmap_df(multiple_species_info_no_sd, species_define) #> # A tibble: 3 × 6 #>     AOU scientific_name mean_size sd_size sd_method              sim_species_id #>   <int> <chr>               <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>                           <int> #> 1    NA NA                     10   0.693 SD estimated from mean              1 #> 2    NA NA                     40   2.80  SD estimated from mean              2 #> 3    NA NA                     50   3.51  SD estimated from mean              3

code: @Manual{,   title = {birdsize: Estimate Avian Body Size Distributions},   author = {Renata Diaz},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://github.com/diazrenata/birdsize}, }

title: Estimate Avian Body Size Distributions
text: birdsize simulates body mass (g) measurements birds. avian monitoring methodologies often rely auditory visual cues, datasets bird populations communities often lack measurements body mass individuals. Without information individuals’ body size, challenging conduct large-scale analyses trends biomass, energy use, community body size structure, , similar patterns species. birdsize addresses need using species’ traits generate size estimates birds based species identity user-specified parameters. Specifically, birdsize assumes body mass normally distributed within species, species-specific mean standard deviation. birdsize uses species-level parameters (mean standard deviation) make estimates individual-level body mass drawing corresponding normal distributions. () broad nature assumptions, birdsize probably used generate fine-scale estimates body mass. Rather, estimates generated birdsize suitable broad-scale macroecological studies, scenario exploration (via tweaking parameters), otherwise impossible given logistical constraints collecting individual body mass measurements massive scale. birdsize contains built-species-level parameters 450 species (mostly found North America north Mexico). also designed take user-provided parameters generate body size estimates species included built-data, indeed hypothetical simulated species. birdsize can generate estimates populations (one many individuals, species) communities (multiple populations different species, species different locations points time).

what: birdsize and the Breeding Bird Survey
title: Estimate Avian Body Size Distributions
text: birdsize originally developed applied North American Breeding Bird Survey (BBS). brief, North American Breeding Bird Survey community science program run USGS 60 years. year, avian breeding season, volunteer surveyors conduct auditory point-counts birds observed along 50-km routes. nearly 3,000 routes distributed across United States Canada, making BBS invaluable dataset avian populations community structure time large geographic extents. detail BBS, access BBS data, see Breeding Bird Survey website repository ScienceBase. facilitate applications BBS, birdsize contains built-species parameters 450 species found BBS 1980 present, contains built-“demo” datasets mimic structure BBS data. bbs-data vignette illustrates use birdsize generate estimates biomass energy use route Breeding Bird Survey. Note, however, birdsize contain actual data Breeding Bird Survey. multiple interfaces connecting BBS data releases (e.g. R Data Retriever, ScienceBase) , wherever possible, users encouraged go directly source access --date data.

title: Estimate Avian Body Size Distributions
text: install -development version: Note , package depends R>= 2.10, vignettes use base R pipe (|>), introduced R 4.1.0.

what: Estimating body masses for a population
title: Estimate Avian Body Size Distributions
text: core functionality birdsize simulate individual body mass measurements birds given either species ID mean (possibly standard deviation) body mass, drawing individuals normal distribution. minimum, requires population size (abundance) either species’ mean body size, species’ identifier (scientific name, AOU numeric code species found BBS). standard deviation body mass provided, birdsize estimate based scaling relationship mean standard deviation body mass. key function pop_generate. , generate body mass estimates population hypothetical species mean body size 10g:  Alternatively, species known birdsize, can simply provide scientific name AOU code. , Melanerpes carolinus red-headed woodpecker:
code: set.seed(13)  first_population <- pop_generate(   abundance = 100,   mean_size = 10 )  hist(first_population$individual_mass,   main = "First population masses",   xlab = "Body mass (g)" ) woodpecker_population <- pop_generate(   abundance = 100,   scientific_name = "Melanerpes carolinus" )  hist(first_population$individual_mass,   main = "M. carolinus population masses",   xlab = "Body mass (g)" )

what: Estimating body masses for a whole community
title: Estimate Avian Body Size Distributions
text: generate body size estimates whole community, use community_generate function. community_generate takes population sizes species identifiers parameters multiple species, simulates populations species. can create estimates hypothetical community providing population sizes scientific names:
code: first_community <- data.frame(   abundance = c(50, 100, 150),   scientific_name = c("Melanerpes carolinus", "Myiarchus crinitus", "Sayornis phoebe") )  first_community_sims <- community_generate(first_community, abundance_column_name = "abundance")  hist(first_community_sims$individual_mass, main = "Community body size distribution", xlab = "Body mass", breaks = 50)

title: Estimate Avian Body Size Distributions
text: Diaz, Renata M. (2023). birdsize: Estimate Avian Body Size Distributions. GitHub. https://github.com/diazrenata/birdsize

title: Simulate individual measurements for many populations — community_generate
Simulate individual measurements for many populations — community_generate
text: community_data_table dataframe containing least one AOU, scientific_name, mean_size column species abundances abundance_column_name character, name column species abundances. Defaults "speciestotal".

title: Simulate individual measurements for many populations — community_generate
text: dataframe one row per individual, columns community_data_table, additional columns species attributes. Specifically: AOU: AOU, provided sim_species_id: sim_species_id provided genus: genus associated AOU provided, genus provided species: species associated AOU provided, species provided individual_mass: simulated body mass (grams) individual individual_bmr: simulated basal metabolic rate individual mean_size: mean body mass species (.e. parameter used simulation) sd_size: standard deviation body mass species (.e. parameter used simulation) abundance: number individuals simulated species (.e. parameter used simulation) sd_method: method finding standard deviation body mass species scientific_name: scientific name

title: Simulate individual measurements for many populations — community_generate

Unique data identification number. countrynum inherited. Three-digit numerical code country. data, toy countrynum 900. statenum inherited. Two-digit numerical code state, province, territory. data, toy number 99. route inherited. Three-digit code identifying route, unique within states. dataset, 1. rpid inherited. Three-digit run protocol identifier. , set 101. year inherited. Four-digit year survey. AOU inherited. Five-digit species identification number. count10 inherited. Total individuals species recorded stops 1-10. count20 inherited. Total individuals species recorded stops 11-20. count30 inherited. Total individuals species recorded stops 21-30. count40 inherited. Total individuals species recorded stops 31-40. count50 inherited. Total individuals species recorded stops 40-50. stoptotal inherited. Total number stops (50), species recorded. speciestotal inherited. Total individuals species recorded across entire run route (sum stops).

what: Estimate parameters for scaling of standard deviation with mean body size — get_sd_parameters
title: Estimate parameters for scaling of standard deviation with mean body size — get_sd_parameters
text: Calculates parameters (log-log linear) scaling relationship mean standard deviation species' mean body size. Given table species known mean standard deviation body sizes, fits linear model form log(var(body_size)) ~ log(mean(body_size)) extracts parameter estimates, can used estimate standard deviation body mass species based mean body mass. See also Thibault et al. (2011) method applied Breeding Bird Survey.

title: Estimate parameters for scaling of standard deviation with mean body size — get_sd_parameters

title: Estimate parameters for scaling of standard deviation with mean body size — get_sd_parameters

(2019), filtered remove species poorly sampled via Breeding Bird Survey methods (following Harris et al. 2018) augmented records, species, mean (, available, standard deviation) body size  found CRC Handbook Avian Body Masses (Dunning 2008). often multiple records species, different sexes locations. record included separate line.

(2019) genus genus, Paradieck et al. (2019) species species, Paradieck et al. (2019) mass mean body size sex/location, Dunning (2008), grams sd standard deviation body size sex/location, provided Dunning (2008). Contains NA records without standard deviation measurements sex sex, provided Dunning (2008). Conatins NA records without values "sex" Dunning (2008). m f subspecies subspecies, Dunning (2008). Contains NA record subspecies listed Dunning (2008) location location, provided Dunning (2008) name_mismatch flag = 1, mismatch scientific name Paradieck et al. (2019) versus Dunning (2008). Typically small changes spelling name_notes name listed Dunning (2008), different listed Paradieck et al. (2019) not_in_dunning flag = 1, species record Dunning (2008) close_genus species Dunning (2008), closely related species - e.g. recently renamed, taxonomically divided 2008 2019 - , genus closely related species. close_species species Dunning (2008), closely related species - e.g. recently renamed, taxonomically divided 2008 2019 - , species closely related species. close_subspecies species Dunning (2008), closely related species - e.g. recently renamed, taxonomically divided 2008 2019 - , subspecies closely related species. close_species_notes notes explaining details "closely related" species designations AOU AOU

what: Species-level means for the mean and standard deviation of body size for species in the North American Breeding Bird Survey. — sd_table
title: Species-level means for the mean and standard deviation of body size for species in the North American Breeding Bird Survey. — sd_table
text: table species-level mean values means standard deviations body size species North American Breeding Bird Survey (Paradieck et al. 2019) based records CRC Handbook Avian Body Masses (2008). Standard deviations, provided CRC Handbook, estimated based scaling relationship species' mean body size standard deviation body size (see also Thibault et al. 2010). Species-level means reported mean mean mass mean standard deviation species.

title: Species-level means for the mean and standard deviation of body size for species in the North American Breeding Bird Survey. — sd_table
Species-level means for the mean and standard deviation of body size for species in the North American Breeding Bird Survey. — sd_table
text: data frame 443 rows 6 variables: AOU AOU used Paradieck et al. (2019) genus genus, Paradieck et al. (2019) species species, Paradieck et al. (2019) mean_mass mean mass across records Dunning (2008) species, grams mean_sd mean standard deviation body mass across records Dunning (2008). records standard deviation provided, standard deviation estimated based scaling relationship derived dataset. Estimated standard deviations calculated prior taking species-level means. contains_estimates TRUE/FALSE whether mean_sd column includes estimated standard deviations scientific_name genus species together

text: AOU numeric AOU code used species Breeding Bird Survey scientific_name species' scientific name, "Genus species" mean_size mean body size sd_size sd body size sim_species_id identifier; using taxonomic info, defaults AOU. , defaults 1. Supplying values can useful simulation models.

title: Define a species — species_define
text: identifying information used depends parameters provided, following order preference: AOU > scientific name > user provided mean sd > user provided mean estimated sd.

title: Define a species — species_define
code: species_define(AOU = 2881) #> $AOU #> [1] 2881 #>  #> $scientific_name #> [1] "Perdix perdix" #>  #> $mean_size #> [1] 405.5 #>  #> $sd_size #> [1] 31 #>  #> $sd_method #> [1] "AOU lookup" #>  #> $sim_species_id #> [1] 2881 #>  species_define(scientific_name = "Perdix perdix") #> $AOU #> [1] 2881 #>  #> $scientific_name #> [1] "Perdix perdix" #>  #> $mean_size #> [1] 405.5 #>  #> $sd_size #> [1] 31 #>  #> $sd_method #> [1] "Scientific name lookup" #>  #> $sim_species_id #> [1] 2881 #>  species_define(mean_size = 400, sd_size = 30) #> $AOU #> [1] NA #>  #> $scientific_name #> [1] NA #>  #> $mean_size #> [1] 400 #>  #> $sd_size #> [1] 30 #>  #> $sd_method #> [1] "Mean and SD provided" #>  #> $sim_species_id #> [1] 1 #>  species_define(mean_size = 400) #> $AOU #> [1] NA #>  #> $scientific_name #> [1] NA #>  #> $mean_size #> [1] 400 #>  #> $sd_size #> [1] 28.55916 #>  #> $sd_method #> [1] "SD estimated from mean" #>  #> $sim_species_id #> [1] 1 #>
